fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a simplicial group G, a fiber bundle p : E \to B is principal if G acts on the fibers freely and transitively on the right. This condition can be checked in each dimension separately.

Given a simplicial principal fiber bundle p : E \to B with simplicial group G, and a simplicial set F with a group action G \times F \to F, we can construct a fiber bundle with fiber F, such that the twisting behaviour is described by the principal bundle p.

We consider a group action on E \times F, by g \cdot (e, f) = (e \cdot g^{-1}, g \cdot f). This action is clearly free. Suppose the quotient simplicial set is E', then we have a simplicial fiber bundle p' : E' \to B induced from p. There is a G-action on the fibers, by acting on the F factor.

Given a simplicial set B, a simplicial group G with a twisting function \tau , the twisted product is the pullback B \times _{\bar {W} G} W G with the W-bar construction. We write B \times _\tau G so as to make explicit the twisting function. This is a simplicial principal fiber bundle.

More explicitly, we define B \times _\tau G to be the same as the Cartesian product B \times G, but with one face map altered. The pair (b, g) represents the element in B \times _{\bar {W} G} W G whose first component is b \in B, and the second component is (g_0, \dots , g_n) \in W G, where each element is an iterated product \begin {aligned} g_n &= g \\ g_{k-1} &= \tau (\partial _{k+1} \cdots \partial _n b) \cdot (\partial _{k} g_{k}). \end {aligned} This forces the last face map to be \partial _n (b, g) = (\partial _n b, \tau (b) \cdot \partial _n g), and the other face and degeneracy maps are unchanged.

Given a simplicial group, we can define a model of its universal principal bundle \mathbf {E} G \to \mathbf {B} G as simplicial sets W G \to \bar {W} G. This is a generalization of the bar construction, if we consider a group G as a discrete simplicial set. It classifies principal G-bundles in the sense of Theorem 21.13 in Simplicial objects in algebraic topology.

We define the n-simplices of W G to be (W G)_n = G_0 \times G_1 \times \cdots \times G_n so that G_n acts on (W G)_n by taking the face map that discards the last k vertices for each k, and then acting on the appropriate factor on the right. This forces the face maps and degeneracy maps to be \begin {aligned} \partial _k (g_0, \dots , g_n) &= (g_0, \dots , g_{k-1}, \partial _k g_{k+1}, \dots , \partial _k g_n), \\ \sigma _k (g_0, \dots , g_n) &= (g_0, \dots , g_{k}, \sigma _k g_{k}, \dots , \sigma _k g_n). \end {aligned} We define \bar {W} G to be W G quotiented by the action of G. This can be represented as (\bar {W} G)_n = G_0 \times \cdots \times G_{n-1}, with the quotient map (W G)_n \twoheadrightarrow (\bar {W} G)_n given by (g_0, \dots , g_n) \mapsto (g_0 (\partial _1 g_1)^{-1}, \dots , g_{n-1} (\partial _n g_n)^{-1}). The face and degeneracy maps can then be computed to be \begin {aligned} \partial _k (g_0, \dots , g_{n-1}) &= (g_0, g_1, \dots , g_{k-1} \cdot \partial _k g_k, \partial _k g_{k+1}, \dots , \partial _k g_{n-1}), \\ \partial _n (g_0, \dots , g_{n-1}) &= (g_0, g_1, \dots , g_{n-2}) \\ \sigma _k (g_0, \dots , g_{n-1}) &= (g_0, g_1, \dots , g_{k-1}, 1, \sigma _k g_{k}, \dots , \sigma _k g_{n-1}). \end {aligned} A quick computation shows that this indeed produces a simplicial principal fiber bundle with fiber G.

A (strict) simplicial fiber bundle p : E \to B with fiber F is a simplicial map p such that for every simplex \Delta ^n \to B, the pullback of p along the simplex is isomorphic to \Delta ^n \times F \to \Delta ^n.
